fields.Name: How to Use Real Work Due to Flexural Strains?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Let's illustrate how to solve the deflections of beams using the real work method. We shall demonstrate how to solve the deflection at a point applied with a structural load.

fields.Name: What are Structural Joints and Connections?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Structural joints or connections are specific points in a structure where members are connected. These influence the structure's behavior. It can be rigid, semi-rigid, or flexible.

fields.Name: Other Analysis Concepts
fields.SEO: Post Summary: These posts explain the various structural concepts you may encounter while studying structural analysis such as boundary conditions, superposition, etc.

fields.Name: How to Perform Truss Analysis?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: This post shows an example of a complete truss analysis - stability, reactions, internal force, and deflections. It is an illustration of what a typical truss analysis is.

fields.Name: Analyzing the Cantilever Beam
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The cantilever is one of the most common beams. We'll explore a complete structural overview of this structure - its model, loads, analysis, and design.

fields.Name: How to Use Virtual Work Due to Axial Strains?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Let's illustrate how to solve the deflections of trusses using the virtual work method. We shall demonstrate how to solve the movement of a truss joint and the rotation of a member.

fields.Name: Introduction to Fluid Mechanics
fields.SEO: Post Summary: This series of posts shows the basic concepts when studying fluids. We'll learn what is a fluid, its different properties, fluid pressure, force, and resistance.

fields.Name: What is Structural Rigidity?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: A fundamental property in any structure is its ability to resist deflection or deformation from loads. We call this rigidity (or stiffness) of a structure.

fields.Name: Ellipse
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The ellipse is one of the conic sections. Let's explore its definition, shape, and geometry through the following series.

fields.Name: What are Trigonometric Functions?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Trigonometric functions are transcendental functions in which the mathematical expression solely consists of a trigonometric operation such as sine, cosine, tangent, etc.

fields.Name: What is A Differential Equation?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: A differential equation (DE) is an equation that consists of derivates of the dependent variable. This post is a basic introduction to the world of differential equations.

fields.Name: How to Use Partial Derivative Method Due to Axial Strains?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Let's illustrate how to solve the deflections of trusses using the partial derivative method. We shall demonstrate how to solve the rotation of a truss member.

fields.Name: How to Analyze Deflection?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: When a structure experiences loads, every structural point will deform and deflect from its original position. This post serves as an introduction to this event.

fields.Name: Mechanics
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Mechanics is a subfield of Physics that aims to understand the connections among force, work, energy, and motion. It is a broad field with countless applications.

fields.Name: Introduction to Mathematical Functions
fields.SEO: Post Summary: In this series of posts, we'll explore a basic introduction to mathematical relations and functions - it's meaning and importance in representing real-life events.

fields.Name: Analyzing the Structural Truss
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Truss analysis is studying the truss's behavior imposed with loads. In this series of posts, we'll explore different examples of how to analyze trusses.

fields.Name: Analysis Methods of the Classical Approach
fields.SEO: Post Summary: In this series of posts, we'll explore the structural methods we may use for a complete analysis - stability, reaction, internal force, and deflection.

fields.Name: Solving Volume By Integration
fields.SEO: Post Summary: This series of posts explores how to use integration to solve volumes. This includes the volumes of solids with similar sections, the volume generated by a solid of revolution, and more.

fields.Name: How to Evaluate Shear and Moment?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Evaluating shear and moment using equations is similar to evaluating mathematical functions. Get the input, feed it into the shear or moment function, then compute the output.

fields.Name: What is Gravitational Force?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Gravitational force, or weight, deals with the pulling force between two objects due to gravity. Mathematically, it is equal to the product of scalar mass and vector acceleration due to gravity.

fields.Name: What is Minima and Maxima?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Most mathematical functions will have extrema (singular: extremum) which are the maximum and minimum points along its curve. Extrema can be classified either as maxima or minima.

fields.Name: How to Use Virtual Work to Solve Flexural Deflections?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Let's explore how to compute the deflection of our beam example using the Virtual Work Method. We shall use this to illustrate how to use the method to find the slope and translation at a point.

fields.Name: Differential Calculus
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Differential calculus is a subfield of calculus that deals with rates of change between quantities. We explore multiple concepts such as limits, derivatives, and more.

fields.Name: Introduction to Derivatives
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Derivatives show the rate of change of a mathematical function - between the inputs and outputs. It is a fundamental concept in differential calculus.

fields.Name: How to Peform Force Analysis for Pin-Connected Frames?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: This post shows the internal force analysis of our pin-connected frame example for every member. It shows how to determine the axial, shear, and moment diagrams.

fields.Name: Solving Differential Equations Graphically
fields.SEO: Post Summary: We can approximate the general solution curves of a differential equation using graphical means. It involves plotting the slope using multiple coordinates to create a slope field.

fields.Name: How to Solve Work with Varying Force?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Variable forces occur when the magnitude of the force varies as position changes. Unlike constant forces, the computation for total work will not be straightforward in these instances.

fields.Name: Deriving Partial Derivative Method Due to Axial Strains
fields.SEO: Post Summary: This post expands on the general partial derivative work expression derived earlier to consider deflection under axial strains. In the end, we can derive the equations used to compute axial deflections.

fields.Name: How to Solve Cantilever Deflection Easily?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: When analyzing the cantilever beam's deflection formulas, we can quickly get its expression under certain loading conditions. Let's explore these formulas.

fields.Name: Applications of Differential Calculus
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Differential calculus has countless applications in the real world. Let's explore these and see how we can use calculus to solve various problems.

fields.Name: How to Analyze Internal Force and Stresses?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Part of any analysis is to determine the internal force and stress the structure is experiencing. We'll discover how to find the structure's axial, shear, moment, and torsional forces.

fields.Name: Basics of Deflection Analysis
fields.SEO: Post Summary: In this series of posts, we explore the various concepts, ideas, and theories in determining the deflection of any structure.

fields.Name: What are Artificial Constraints?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: In constructing conjugate beams, we must change the supports of the actual beam to match the deflection behavior. These supports of the conjugate beam are what we call artificial constraints.

fields.Name: How to Perform Beam Analysis?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: This post shows an example of a complete beam analysis - stability, reactions, internal force, and deflections. It is an illustration of what a typical beam analysis is.

fields.Name: Free Fall Motion
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Free fall motion is a type of rectilinear motion in which a body moves under the sole force of gravity alone. We'll explore the event, describe its motion, and investigate special variations of it.

fields.Name: What is Terminal Velocity?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The terminal velocity of a free fall object occurs when the resistance force has gained enough magnitude to equate with gravitational pull. It is the point the falling object never gains any more speed.

fields.Name: Integral Calculus
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Integral calculus is a subfield that deals with the integral - making things complete as a whole. Integration is the inverse of the differentiation operation.

fields.Name: Engineering
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Engineering is the art of problem-solving. It is the application of various concepts and ideas in Mathematics and Sciences to create solutions to everyday problems.

fields.Name: How to Use Partial Derivative Method Due to Flexural Strains?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Let's illustrate how to solve the deflections of beams using the partial derivative method. We shall demonstrate how to solve the deflection at a certain point along a beam.

fields.Name: Analyzing the Structural Frame
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Frame analysis is studying the frame's behavior imposed with loads. In this series of posts, we'll explore different examples of how to analyze frames.

fields.Name: What is the Second Derivative?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The second derivative measures the rate of change of the first derivative (or the slope of function). It also tells us the concavity of the said function.

fields.Name: Statically Determinate and Indeterminate Structures
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Structures can either be statically determinate or indeterminate. The former can be analyzed using static equilibrium equations only while the latter cannot be analyzed using such equations only.

fields.Name: How to Name Mathematical Functions?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: To easily identify functions, we can name mathematical functions with different notations. Let's explore the different ways how to notate such components.

fields.Name: Deriving Free Fall with Air Resistance
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The following series of posts shows the derivation of position, velocity, and acceleration with respect to time for free fall motion with fluid resistance.

fields.Name: Orienting the Parabola
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The parabola can be oriented in different ways. The most common orientations are vertical and horizontal parabolas. We'll explore the properties of each in this post.

fields.Name: What Are Mathematical Functions?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Mathematical functions are relations that observe the one-to-one or many-to-one type of connection. It is one of the most fundamental concepts in Mathematics.

fields.Name: Deriving Real Work Due to Axial Strains
fields.SEO: Post Summary: This post expands on the general real work expression derived earlier to consider deflection under axial strains. In the end, we can derive the equations used to compute axial deflections.

fields.Name: What are the Derivative Tests?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Derivative tests are ways we can use to determine if an extremum of a function is a maximum or a minimum. We can use these two methods: the first and second derivative tests.

fields.Name: What is the Method of Bar Conversions?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The Method of Bar Conversions is a procedure for solving the internal bar forces of complex trusses. It is a unique procedure that makes use of a number of analysis concepts.

fields.Name: Structural Modeling
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Structural modeling is one of the stages in structural design. It involves creating the skeleton frame of the structure itself. Let's explore more in this series of posts.

fields.Name: What are Conic Sections?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The conic sections are special geometric figures that were derived from the making cuts in the double-napped cone. These figures have countless applications in various fields.

fields.Name: How to Model Free Fall with Air Resistance?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: In this post, we shall explore free fall motion with the effect of fluid resistance. Let's explore how to consider this factor when modeling such events.

fields.Name: What is Tangential Deviation?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The second theorem of the Area Moment Method states that "the tangential deviation of point 2 from point 1 is equal to the first moment of the area of the flexural moment divided by flexural rigidity diagram."

fields.Name: Calculus
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Calculus - the mathematical study of change. In this field, we explore concepts such as limits, derivatives, differentiation, integration, and more.

fields.Name: Classical Approach
fields.SEO: Post Summary: In this series of posts, we'll explore the classical approach when analyzing structures. It serves as the backbone of the entire structural analysis process.

fields.Name: Modeling Axial Force
fields.SEO: Post Summary: This series of posts shows how to determine the axial force experienced by a structural member. We'll explore the method of joints and sections, to name a few.

fields.Name: Solving Differential Equations Numerically
fields.SEO: Post Summary: We can use a numerical approach, called Euler's Method, to solve differential equations. It is an approximation method in which we use a table of values to find a solution.

fields.Name: Analyzing the Internal Force and Stresses of a Beam
fields.SEO: Post Summary: In this series of posts, we'll explore how to solve our beam example's internal force and stresses using various methods and techniques - another essential requirement for analysis.

fields.Name: Trigonometry
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Trigonometry is the mathematical study of relationships between angles and lengths. At the heart of trigonometry is the triangle - arguably one of the most important shapes.

fields.Name: How to Use Moment By Parts?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: This post illustrates how to construct the moment diagram of a beam structure using Moment By Parts. We shall explore how making this diagram differs from a usual moment diagram.

fields.Name: Geometry
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Geometry is the mathematical study of space. In this branch, we explore ideas such as distance, size, shape, position, area, volume, and more. Start your geometric journey here.

fields.Name: How to Solve Volume Using Integration?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: We can determine the volume of a solid with similar cross-sections using definite integrals. In this post, let's explore how it expands the approximate solution.

fields.Name: Geometry of the Hyperbola
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The hyperbola is a set of all points in which the absolute value of the difference of its distances from two unique points (foci) is constant.

fields.Name: What are Boundary Conditions?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Boundary conditions are forces or deflections at specific points of the structure that we already know from the very start. They serve as additional information that helps us analyze the structure.

fields.Name: How to Analyze Truss Stability?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: In this post, we'll explore the trusses' external and internal stability using different examples - a significant requirement in analyzing any structure.

fields.Name: What are Structural References?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: When creating a structural model, it's important to create a reference system in which we can refer our components. In this way, we can have a uniform representation of the model.

fields.Name: What is Equilibrium?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The principle of equilibrium is the basis of most structural analysis methods. It describes the structure's state and deals with balance. Let's explore this idea in more detail.

fields.Name: How Do We Classify Frames?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: We can arrange the members of a structural frame in any way possible. Two typical configurations are (1) portal and (2) gable frames. Let's explore the difference.

fields.Name: Parabola
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The parabola is one of the conic sections. Let's explore its definition, shape, and geometry through the following series.

fields.Name: Applications of Differential Equations
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Differential equations have countless applications in real-life. This post explores some of these in various fields and disciplines - how it fits in solving real-world problems.

fields.Name: How to Perform Frame Analysis?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: This post shows an example of a complete frame analysis - stability, reactions, internal force, and deflections. It is an illustration of what a typical frame analysis is.

fields.Name: How to Use the Area Moment Method Using Moment By Parts?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Let's explore how to compute the deflection of our beam example using the Area Moment Method. In this post, let's use moment-by-parts to calculate the slope and translation at a certain point.

fields.Name: How to Get the Area and Centroid of Cantilever Moment Diagrams Easily?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: When analyzing the cantilever beam's moment diagram, we can quickly get its area and centroid under certain loading conditions. Let's explore these patterns.

fields.Name: How to Analyze Special Compound Trusses?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: This is an example of a compound truss analysis and an illustration of how we can quickly analyze it by identifying its connection elements between the simple trusses.

fields.Name: Why Learn Functions?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Mathematical functions are expressions we can use to model real-life situations. It's a way to help us understand the problem and create solutions for it.

fields.Name: Analyzing the Internal Force and Stresses of a Truss
fields.SEO: Post Summary: In this series of posts, we'll explore how to solve our truss example's internal force and stresses using various methods and techniques - another essential requirement for analysis.

fields.Name: Deriving Virtual Work Due to Axial Strains
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Let's expand on the general virtual work expression derived earlier to consider deflection under axial strains. Ultimately, we can derive the equations used to compute axial deflections.

fields.Name: Solving Differential Equations
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The following posts are the different ways how to solve differential equations. We'll explore how to solve these using different approaches - analytical, numerical, and graphical.

fields.Name: How to Solve Homogeneous Equations?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Homogeneous differential equations are another approach to solving differential equations analytically. It's a unique method applicable to homogeneous functions.

fields.Name: What are Common Truss Types?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: There are many different truss patterns in real life - each has its own purpose. In this post, we'll explore some of the common configurations one may encounter.

fields.Name: Deriving the General Virtual Work Equation
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Continuing from the naming convention, we'll explore the general equation of the virtual work method - setting the variables and deriving the expression.

fields.Name: How to Solve Deflections Using the Partial Derivative Method?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The partial derivative method, or Castigliano's second theorem, breaks the limitation of the real work method in solving structural deflections. We'll explore the general derivation in this post.

fields.Name: How to Find the Arc of a Curve Using Integration?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: We can determine the arc of any curve using definite integrals. In this post, let's explore how it expands the approximate solution of solving arc lengths.

fields.Name: Plane and Spatial Structures
fields.SEO: Post Summary: In real-life, structures are all three-dimensional objects; however, we can analyze structures as a plane or space structure. This would depend on the arrangement of its components in space.

fields.Name: How to Investigate Internal Force?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Internal forces are experienced by an object when an external force acts on it. In this post, we'll explore how to investigate these forces which would depend on an exploratory section.

fields.Name: Mathematics
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Mathematics - the encompassing field that deals with the study of numbers, structure, geometry, and change. Start here to begin your Mathematics journey.

fields.Name: How to Use the Conjugate Beam Method?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Let's explore how to compute the deflection of our beam example using the Conjugate Beam Method. We shall use this to illustrate how to use the method to find the slope and translation at a point.

fields.Name: How to Solve the Surface Area of a Solid of Revolution?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: We can determine the surface area generated by a solid of revolution using definite integrals. In this post, let's explore how it expands the approximate solution.

fields.Name: What is a Structural Member?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: A structural member is a long slender component of a structure. In this post, we'll explore more of this element, such as its longitudinal and transverse properties.

fields.Name: Types of Mathematical Functions
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Functions can be classified into certain types. One common classification is to categorize it as either algebraic or transcendental. We'll explore the difference between the two.

fields.Name: Linear and Nonlinear Analysis
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Structural analysis can also be classified as either linear or nonlinear. This depends on the material stress and strain as loads apply to the structure.

fields.Name: How to Intepret Conjugate Beam Results and Deflections?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: This post explains more on the analog between the conjugate beam and the real beam - specifically, the directions of the conjugate shear and moment to real slope and translation.

fields.Name: The Conics
fields.SEO: Post Summary: There are four conic sections: circle, parabola, ellipse, and hyperbola. Each figure deserves its study. Let's explore these figures in the following section.

fields.Name: How to Solve the Volume Using the Disc Method?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: We can determine the volume of a solid with similar cross-sections using definite integrals. In this post, let's explore the disc method in finding the volume of a solid of revolution.

fields.Name: Deriving Real Work Due to Flexural Strains
fields.SEO: Post Summary: This post expands on the general real work expression derived earlier to consider deflection under flexural strains. In the end, we can derive the equations used to compute flexural deflections.

fields.Name: What are Shear and Moment Relationships?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: We continue our analysis of our beam example by constructing the moment diagram. This time, we shall relate the shear values to draw the moment graph.

fields.Name: Solving Differential Equations Analytically
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The analytic approach in solving differential equations is a straightforward way to find its solution. There are multiple ways how to solve it depending on the case. Let's explore each in this series of posts.

fields.Name: How to Solve First Order Linear Differential Equations?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The first-order linear differential equation is a unique expression. When a math equation is in this form, we can solve it analytically using a predefined method.

fields.Name: How to Solve the Volume Using the Washer Method?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: We can determine the volume of a solid with similar cross-sections using definite integrals. In this post, let's explore the washer method in finding the volume of a solid of revolution.

fields.Name: How to Perform Force Analysis for Frames?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Let's explore how to analyze the internal force of every member and joint of our rigid portal frame example - a crucial step when analyzing any structure.

fields.Name: What are the Types of Structural Loads?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: There are many ways how to classify structural loads. In this post, we'll explore the different common loads that we may encounter - dead, live, wind, earthquake, etc.

fields.Name: What are Load, Shear, and Moment Relationships?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: There is a relationship among the external loads, shear, and moment that is extremely useful, especially when creating shear and moment diagrams without the equations.

fields.Name: How to Derive Free Fall Model with Drag Resistance (Velocity-Time)?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: This post shows the derivation of the model between two motion variables, velocity and time, of an object experiencing free-fall motion with drag resistance.

fields.Name: How to Use the Area Moment Method Using Integration?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Let's explore how to compute the deflection of our beam example using the Area Moment Method. In this post, let's use integration to calculate the slope and translation at a certain point.

fields.Name: Differential Equations
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Differential equations are mathematical expressions that consist of either differentials or derivatives. These equations enable us to expand our ways on how to describe real-world phenomena.

fields.Name: How to Perform Force Analysis for Gable Frames?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: This post shows the internal force analysis of our rigid gable frame example for every member. It shows how to determine the axial, shear, and moment diagrams.

fields.Name: What is Conjugate Shear?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The first conjugate beam theorem states that the fictional shear of the conjugate beam at any point is the rotation (slope) of the actual beam at said point.

fields.Name: Orienting the Ellipse
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The ellipse can be oriented in different ways. The most common ones are horizontal and vertical ellipses. Let's explore the properties of these two orientations.

fields.Name: Introduction to Work Methods
fields.SEO: Post Summary: One of the most powerful methods in solving for the deflection of structures are the work methods which consists of virtual and real work. As preparation, we'll review several concepts.

fields.Name: What Are Structural Loads?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Structural loads are forces that cause stress and deformations to structures. One must adequately identify the loads one will experience during its lifetime.

fields.Name: Structural Engineering
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Structural engineering is a subdiscipline of civil engineering that deals with investigating, analyzing, and designing civil structures - shelters, buildings, etc.

fields.Name: How Do We Describe Members at Cross-Section?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Cross-section properties of a structural member refer to properties when we're investigating a cut section of it. Examples include symmetry, shape, and more.

fields.Name: Trigonometric Identities
fields.SEO: Post Summary: When the output of a trigonometric expression is equal to another trigonometric expression, we can say that these two are identities. In this series of posts, we'll explore the most common ones.

fields.Name: Analyzing the Structural Beam
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Beam analysis is all about studying the beam's behavior imposed with loads. In this series of posts, we'll explore different examples of how to analyze beams.

fields.Name: What is the Double Integration Method?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The Double Integration Method is an analytical procedure for solving beam deflections. This method aims to find an expression for the structure's deflected shape through a function.

fields.Name: What is a Differential Equation Solution?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: A solution is the answer to a differential equation. It can practically be thought of as removing the expression's derivatives and/or differentials.

fields.Name: How to Solve Bernoulli Equations?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The Bernoulli Equation is an expression that is nearly similar to the First Order Linear Differential Equation; Solving it analytically involves converting the former to the latter.

fields.Name: How to Use the Area Moment Method to Find the Maximum Deflection?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Let's explore how to compute the maximum deflection of our beam example using the Area Moment Method. It serves as an illustration of how to find it and calculate for it.

fields.Name: How to Solve the Area Between Curves Using Integration?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: We can determine the area between curves using definite integrals. In this post, let's explore how it expands the approximate solution of solving area.

fields.Name: How to Analyze Gable Frames?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Let's consider the example of how to analyze rigid gable frames. We'll explore its stability, reaction analysis of its supports, and internal force analysis of every member.

fields.Name: How Do We Classify Beams?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The structural beam can be classified into two configurations: simple or compound beam. There's a simple difference between the two. Let's explore both of these arrangements.

fields.Name: What is Superposition?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Superposition allows you to add reactions, internal forces, and deflection of similar structures with different loading conditions to get a combined similar structure.

fields.Name: What is Drag Equation?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The drag equation is an expansion of fluid resistance. It accounts for factors such as the body's size and shape and the fluid's composition, to name a few.

fields.Name: How Do We Classify Trusses?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The structural truss can be classified into three configurations: simple, compound, or complex. Let's explore a brief overview of these arrangements.

fields.Name: Geometry of the Parabola
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The parabola is a conic section in which its locus is the set of all points equidistant to a fixed point called the focus and a fixed line called the directrix.

fields.Name: Structural Loads
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Analysis of structural loads is another stage of the whole structural design process. In this stage, we analyze the external forces that act on the structure.

fields.Name: How to Analyze Beam Stability?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: In this post, we'll explore the beam's external and internal stability using different examples - a significant requirement in analyzing any structure.

fields.Name: How to Use the Method of Bar Conversions?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: This post expands on our complex truss example by showing the complete solution of every member's internal axial bar force using the Method of Bar Conversions.

fields.Name: What are Structural Supports?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Structural supports are responsible for keeping objects or structures restrained in space. They must control movement at their application point and carry the structure's applied external loads.

fields.Name: What is the Logistic Differential Equation?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The logistic differential equation deals with modeling growth or decay events with a certain limit. Let's explore more about this unique modeling event.

fields.Name: Where Do Loads Come From?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Structural loads come from various sources. The most common ones are from the environment such as gravity, wind, etc. Other sources include man-made such as construction or usage.

fields.Name: What is External and Internal Force?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Forces can be classified as either external or internal. The former is when the force experienced by the body is from the environment, while the latter is inherent to the object.

fields.Name: How Do We Describe Loads?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Structural loads have different properties that we must know when analyzing structures such as spatial application, duration, nature, rate of application, and certainty.

fields.Name: Deriving Virtual Work Due to Flexural Strains
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Let's expand on the general virtual work expression derived earlier to consider deflection under flexural strains. Ultimately, we can derive the equations used to compute flexural deflections.

fields.Name: What are Load and Shear Relationships?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: We continue our analysis of our beam example by constructing the shear diagram. This time, we shall relate the external loads applied to the beam to draw it.

fields.Name: Orienting the Hyperbola
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The hyperbola can be oriented in many ways. Two common orientations are the horizontal and vertical hyperbola. This post shows the properties of the two.

fields.Name: Strength of Materials
fields.SEO: Post Summary: When a deformable object experiences a force, it will experience internal stresses and deformation. The subfield, strength of materials, deals with this phenomenon.

fields.Name: Modeling Shear and Moment
fields.SEO: Post Summary: When a structure experiences flexural loads, it will experience shear and moment. This post serves as an introduction to these two and how we model these.

fields.Name: What is Conjugate Moment?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The second conjugate beam theorem states that the fictional moment of the conjugate beam at any point is the translation (slope) of the actual beam at said point.

fields.Name: How to Solve Optimization Problems?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Optimization problems deal with finding a mathematical function's maximum or minimum. In this post, let's explore how to tackle these real-world problems.

fields.Name: How to Solve Deflections Using Virtual Work?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The virtual work method is arguably one of the most powerful methods in solving structural deflections. In this post, we'll explore the basic naming convention we will use as preparation.

fields.Name: What is the Conjugate Beam Method?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The conjugate beam method is an analytical procedure in which solving deflections is similar to finding a structure's shear and moment. It is an expansion of the area moment method.

fields.Name: How to Analyze Deflections Qualitatively?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: We can analyze deflection qualitatively - approximate the deflected shape of structures based on the support conditions, internal force analysis, and joints.

fields.Name: What is a Beam?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The beam is a long slender member designed to resist loads. It can vary on many properties, but generally, it's a structure that experiences shear and flexural stresses.

fields.Name: What are the Different Analysis Types?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: In this post, we'll explore a basic overview of the different types of analysis used when investigating structures. This serves as an introduction to the big world of structural analysis.

fields.Name: What is Internal Force?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: There are many types of internal forces experienced by a body - axial, shear, moment, and torsion. Let's explore a brief introduction to these forces.

fields.Name: What is Structural Material?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Material properties are important considerations when designing a structure. In this post, we'll explore some properties - anisotropy, homogeneity, and more.

fields.Name: Hyperbola
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The hyperbola is one of the conic sections. Let's explore its definition, shape, and geometry through the following series.

fields.Name: What are Relations?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Relations are links or connections between sets - a collection of similar items. This topic on relations is the first step in learning mathematical functions.

fields.Name: How to Use Virtual Work to Solve Shear and Moment?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: We can use virtual work and the work-energy theorem to solve a structure's reactions and internal forces. This post shows how to use it to solve reactions and internal forces.

fields.Name: What is the Point of Zero Shear?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The point of zero shear is the position along the beam in which the shear is zero. Let's explore different ways to calculate this position using functions or graphs.

fields.Name: Introduction to Structural Engineering
fields.SEO: Post Summary: In this series of posts, let's explore a basic introduction to structural engineering. We answer questions like: What is a structure? How to design structures? And more.

fields.Name: Net Work
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The sum of all work acting on the body is the net work experienced by it. Computing for the total work will depend on the force magnitude, displacement, as well as its application.

fields.Name: How Do Loads Apply On a Structure?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: How loads apply to the structure itself comes in various forms. It may come as a moment/torsion, concentrated point load, linear load, or planar load.

fields.Name: What are Polynomial Functions?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Polynomial functions are algebraic functions in which the mathematical expression is a polynomial - terms consisting of coefficients and variables that are added or subtracted together.

fields.Name: What are Orthogonal Trajectories?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Orthogonal trajectories occur when two curve families are perpendicular to each other at intersection points. This post explains more in detail regarding the concept.

fields.Name: How to Apply Free Fall Model with Air Resistance?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Let's explore free-fall motion with fluid resistance in a real-life scenario and how such motion models help us understand the event.

fields.Name: What is the Structural Model?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The structural model is an engineer's solution to a structural problem. Generally, there are four components of a structure: (1) members, (2) joints, (3) support, and (4) panels.

fields.Name: How to Use the Method of Joints?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: In this post, we'll explore how to solve for the bar force of our truss example using the method of joints - an illustration of how to use this method in analyzing internal forces.

fields.Name: What is a Truss?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The truss is an assemblage of various objects in space. We call the long slender things - members. The end connection of each member is called a joint.

fields.Name: What is the Newton-Raphson Method?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The Newton-Raphson Method (or simply Newton's Method) is a way to approximate the zeroes of the function. We can use it as an alternative to solve functions or equations.

fields.Name: What is Moment By Parts?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Moment By Parts is another approach to express the internal bending moment of a structure. It allows us to compute the area and centroid of the moment graph quickly.

fields.Name: What are Explicit and Implicit Domains?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The domain of a function can be categorized as either explicit or implicit. This would depend on the real-life situation being modeled by the mathematical function.

fields.Name: How to Use Real Work Due to Axial Strains?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Let's illustrate how to solve the deflections of trusses using the real work method. We shall demonstrate how to solve the movement of a truss joint with an applied load.

fields.Name: What are Monomials and Polynomials?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Monomials and polynomials are primary structural units when creating Mathematical expressions. We'll explore more about these components in this post.

fields.Name: How to Analyze Mathematical Functions?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Mathematical functions can be viewed from different perspectives: analytical, graphical, and numerical. Each perspective allows us to see functions from different viewpoints.

fields.Name: How to Solve the Volume Using the Shell Method?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: We can determine the volume of a solid with similar cross-sections using definite integrals. In this post, let's explore the shell method in finding the volume of a solid of revolution.

fields.Name: How to Analyze Compound Beams?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: In this post, let's explore how to analyze compound beams. We shall analyze its stability, the force carried by supports, and the internal force the beam experience.

fields.Name: What is a Structure?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: At its basic, structures are something built. It is an assemblage of structural parts that are strong enough to resist loads and must be usable for everyone.

fields.Name: What is Change in Slope in the Area Moment Method?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The first theorem of the Area Moment Method states that "the change in slope between two points is equal to the area of the flexural moment divided by flexural rigidity diagram between said points."

fields.Name: How to Use the Double Integration Method Using Segment Analysis?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Let's model the deflected shape of the beam using the double integration method. In this post, we'll explore using segmented equations to model the slope and translation.

fields.Name: Area of the Ellipse
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Being a closed conic section, we can compute the area of an ellipse. This post shows a derivation of its area using integration.

fields.Name: How to Analyze Frame Stability?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: In this post, we'll explore the frame's external and internal stability using different examples - a significant requirement in analyzing any structure.

fields.Name: How Do We Categorize Structures?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: We can categorize structures by many classifications. Examples of which are either by function or direction. This post explains more about these two classifications.

fields.Name: What is the First Derivative?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The first derivative tells us the steepness of a mathematical function at a given point. In other words, it is the slope of the math function at said point.

fields.Name: What are the Key Analysis Concepts?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Most analysis methods in structural engineering revolve around the following key concepts: equilibrium principle, compatibility conditions, and constitutive equations.

fields.Name: Structural Analysis
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Structural analysis is one of the stages in the whole design process. In this stage, we analyze the behavior of the structure under the given model and loads.

fields.Name: Introduction to Structural Analysis
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Structural theory starts with discussing the concepts and ideas behind the analysis process. We explore what is a complete analysis, how to perform it, and more.

fields.Name: Solving Area By Integration
fields.SEO: Post Summary: This series of posts explores how to use integration to solve areas. This includes the area between curves, the surface area generated by a solid of revolution, and more.

fields.Name: What is Eccentricity?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: One important characteristic of conic sections is eccentricity - a number from zero to infinity that tells us the classification of the conic shape.

fields.Name: Welcome to the Tree of Knowledge!
fields.SEO: Post Summary: New to WeTheStudy? Start here at the root where all concepts meet. Welcome to the gateway to all ideas!

fields.Name: Deriving Partial Derivative Method Due to Flexural Strains
fields.SEO: Post Summary: This post expands on the general partial derivative work expression derived earlier to consider deflection under flexural strains. In the end, we can derive the equations used to compute flexural deflections.

fields.Name: How to Evaluate Functions?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Evaluating mathematical functions is a simple procedure: substitute the input into the given expression and solve for the output. This post shows how to do so.

fields.Name: Analyzing the Deflection of a Beam
fields.SEO: Post Summary: This series of posts show how to model the beam's deflection. Let's explore how to get our beam example's deflected shape using different methods such as the double integration method, work methods, etc.

fields.Name: What is the Area Moment Method?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The Area Moment Method is an analytical and geometric procedure used to find the deflection of plane beams and frames. It revolves around two concepts that we'll explore in this post.

fields.Name: Investigating The Fundamental Structures
fields.SEO: Post Summary: In this series of posts, we'll explore a basic overview of the different structural units, such as beams, trusses, frames, cables, slabs/shells, and many more.

fields.Name: What are Constitutive Equations?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: One of the fundamental concepts of analysis is constitutive equations. It tells us the relationship between loads and stresses to deformations and strains.

fields.Name: How Do We Arrange Frames?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Structural frames may be categorized depending on the application of loads - plane frame, grid, or space frame. Let's explore these groupings in this post.

fields.Name: What is the Analytical Model?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: An analytical model is an analysis model which serves as a basis for predicting the structure's behavior. It contains information of all structural components as well as its properties.

fields.Name: How to Use the Double Integration Method Using a General Equation?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Let's model the deflected shape of the beam using the double integration method. In this post, we'll explore using a general equation to model the slope and translation.

fields.Name: What are the Parts of a Truss?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The parts of a truss can be classified into many types. In this post, we'll explore terminologies used in structural engineering in naming the different parts.

fields.Name: Kinetics
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Kinetics is a subfield of Mechanics that deals with the relationship between the motion of a body and the forces that cause it. We learn ideas like force and torque - to name a few.

fields.Name: Work and Energy
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Work and energy are two interrelated concepts in Physics. In this series of posts, we'll explore these two ideas and how they fit into real-life situations.

fields.Name: What is Fluid Resistance?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Whenever an object is moving in a fluid, there is a force that resists its motion which we call fluid resistance. Its direction will always be opposite to the body's movement.

fields.Name: What is the Bernoulli-Euler Beam Theory?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Bernoulli and Euler created theories on how beams behave under the influence of loads. In this post, we'll explore the two fundamental assumptions when analyzing beam deflection.

fields.Name: How to Use the Method of Sections?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: In this post, we'll explore how to solve for the bar force of our truss example using the method of sections - an illustration of how to use this method in analyzing internal forces.

fields.Name: Classical and Matrix Approach
fields.SEO: Post Summary: There are generally two approaches in structural analysis: classical and matrix. These two rose due to the development of structural analysis throughout history.

fields.Name: How to Form Shear and Moment Equations?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: In this post, we explore how to construct the shear and moment equations of our beam example - an illustration of how to apply theory to a real-life example.

fields.Name: Algebra
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Algebra is the art of creating mathematical expressions using numbers, constants, and variables and manipulating these components using various operations.

fields.Name: How to Remember Trigonometric Identities Easily?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: This post explores the hexagon mnemonic - a common tool in memorizing trigonometric identities. We'll explore how to use it to get the reciprocal, quotient, and Pythagorean identities.

fields.Name: How to Analyze Geometric Stability?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: When analyzing, the first thing to do is analyze its stability - the structure's ability to retain rigidity and shape when applied with external loads.

fields.Name: Applications of the Definite Integral
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Integration is the process of finding the whole from many parts. In this post, we'll explore the definite integral and how it fits in solving real-life problems.

fields.Name: Static and Dynamic Analysis
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The analysis would also depend on the load, which can either be static or dynamic. Static loads do not generate acceleration effects on the structure, while dynamic does.

fields.Name: How to Derive Free Fall Model with Drag Resistance (Position-Time)?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: This post shows the derivation of the model between two motion variables, position and time, of an object experiencing free-fall motion with drag resistance.

fields.Name: Applications of Classical Approach
fields.SEO: Post Summary: This series of posts shows how to apply the different structural concepts and theories in analyzing structures. It serves as an illustration of how to analyze structures.

fields.Name: Kinematics
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Kinematics is a subfield of Mechanics that deals with the motion of matter without considering the force affecting it. In this field, we deal with ideas like distance, speed, acceleration, and more.

fields.Name: What is Separation of Variables?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The separation of variables is an analytic approach to finding a solution to a differential equation. It involves separating like-variables and differentials to each side of the equation.

fields.Name: How to Analyze Pin-Connected Frames?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Let's consider the example of how to analyze pin-connected frames. We'll explore its stability, reaction analysis of its supports, and internal force analysis of every member.

fields.Name: What is the Point of Zero Moment?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The point of zero moment is the position along the beam in which the moment is zero. Let's explore different ways to calculate this position using functions or graphs.

fields.Name: What are Common Beam Types?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: There are many beam patterns one may encounter in the real-world such as simple, fixed, cantilever, propped, etc. This post shows a brief overview of these.

fields.Name: What are Composite Functions?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: We can place one mathematical function to another to form composite functions. This results in a new expression depending on the phenomenon being modeled.

fields.Name: How to Derive Free Fall Model with Drag Resistance (Acceleration-Time)?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: This post shows the derivation of the model between two motion variables, acceleration and time, of an object experiencing free-fall motion with drag resistance.

fields.Name: What is Newton’s Law of Cooling?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Newton's Law of Cooling states that how fast an object cools over a period is proportional to the difference between the temperature of the object and its surroundings.

fields.Name: What is the Method of Sections?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The method of sections is a procedure we use in truss analysis and is one of the two essential solutions to solve the internal forces of any truss structure.

fields.Name: Analyzing the Internal Force and Stresses of a Frame
fields.SEO: Post Summary: In this series of posts, we'll explore how to solve our frame example's internal force and stresses using various methods and techniques - another essential requirement for analysis.

fields.Name: What is a Frame?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The structural frame is a structure composed of members connected by joints. The members experience all sorts of stresses while the joints are rigid but may be semi-rigid or flexible.

fields.Name: What is Fluid Pressure?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Fluid pressure is the continuous physical force a body experiences when submerged in a fluid. Mathematically, it is the perpendicularly-applied force per unit area.

fields.Name: Fluid Mechanics
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Fluid mechanics deals with studying fluid matter, such as liquids and gases. In this subfield, we'll explore the properties of fluid and concepts like pressure, to name a few.

fields.Name: What is Growth and Decay?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Many of the world's phenomena can be represented by growth and decay. We can do this by representing the factors of the event using a differential equation.

fields.Name: How to Derive Free Fall Model with Simple Resistance (Velocity-Time)?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: This post shows the derivation of the model between two motion variables, velocity and time, of an object experiencing free-fall motion with simple resistance.

fields.Name: How to Evaluate Deflections?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: With slope and translation equations constructed, let's use these expressions to illustrate how to find the deflection at any point of our beam example.

fields.Name: Geometry of the Ellipse
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The ellipse is a conic section in which its locus is the set of all points in which the sum of its distances from two unique points (foci) is constant.

fields.Name: What are Compatibility Conditions
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Compatibility refers to the balance between the structure's deflected shape and the effect of structural loads imposed on it. There must be a reasonable cause-and-effect relationship between the two.

fields.Name: Reviewing Work and Energy in Structural Analysis
fields.SEO: Post Summary: We can analyze a structure using work and energy principles. It's a powerful alternative that helps us see analysis in a new light and expand our methods.

fields.Name: Physics
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Physics is a broad field of study - it is the study of matter and the natural forces and laws that affect it. It also includes its motion and composition at the particle level. It's one of the fundamental science that aims to understand how the universe works.

fields.Name: Structures
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Structures deal with the components that we use to solve problems. We'll learn how to manipulate values through algebra and create expressions using functions.

fields.Name: How to Analyze Beams Using Virtual Work?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: In this post, let's explore how to analyze a beam example using work and energy principles. Using this method, we'll illustrate how to solve for reactions, shear, and moment.

fields.Name: How to Solve Deflections Using Real Work?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: This post serves as an introduction to real work methods. Unlike virtual work, it uses actual forces and displacements to find translations and rotations.

fields.Name: What is the Right Triangle?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The right triangle is a triangle in which one of its angles is a right angle (90 degrees). It serves as a perfect introduction to the world of trigonometry.

fields.Name: Motion
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Motion is a fundamental concept in Kinematics that describe the movement of matter. We'll explore topics such as speed, velocity, and acceleration to name a few.

fields.Name: Relations and Functions
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Relations and functions are essential structures we use to model the real world. Start here and explore one of the most important topics in Mathematics.

fields.Name: How to Analyze Complex Trusses?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: This is an example of a complex truss analysis. We will explore its stability, the amount of force carried by its supports, and the internal forces of each member.

fields.Name: Analytic Geometry
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Analytic Geometry is a subfield of geometry that deals with space in a coordinate system. It allows us to represent geometric figures using Mathematical expressions.

fields.Name: What is Fluid Force?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: A body submerged in a fluid will experience fluid pressure. The equivalent resultant force of such pressure is what we call the fluid force. Let's explore this concept.

fields.Name: How to Solve Deflection?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: This post serves as an introduction to the different ways how to compute for the deflection of various structures. We explore methods such as the double integration method, work methods, and more.

fields.Name: Constructing Mathematical Functions
fields.SEO: Post Summary: This series of posts shows how we construct mathematical functions. We explore concepts like notation, domain, range, and approaches, to name a few.

fields.Name: What is the Method of Joints?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: The method of joints is a procedure we use in truss analysis and is one of the two essential solutions to solve the internal forces of any truss structure.

fields.Name: How to Solve Varying Fluid Force?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Pressure varies depending on the depth. Because of this, the fluid force acting on the object differs depending on the depth; hence, the computation for the total force will require integration.

fields.Name: How to Design Structures?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: We can break the design of civil structures into several stages: (1) modeling, (2) load analysis, (3) structural analysis, and (4) design. Let's explore a basic overview of each stage.

fields.Name: How Do We Describe Members Longitudinally?
fields.SEO: Post Summary: Longitudinal properties of structural members refer to properties that run along their whole length. Examples of these include its extrusion path and uniformity.
